sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In contemporary society a growing number of activities take place 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. This interferes with the possibility of respecting the sleep-wake cycle regulated by the circadian biological clock. The consequent phase shift induces a reduced quantity and quality of sleep which in turn interferes with well-being and health. Sleep disorders and symptoms of reduced duration or quality of sleep can have significant socio-health consequences. The aim of the study is to identify the links between sleep and well-being, in order to propose targeted methods of promoting sleep health.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: A rapid review of the literature was conducted to assess the evidence supporting health promotion programs. A promotion intervention was scheduled in a population at high risk of sleep problems.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Sleep symptoms of reduced quantity or quality or lack of sleep satisfaction are associated with reduced vitality and energy or motivation, impaired work performance, cognitive functioning, emotional regulation, social participation and relationship with colleagues, friends and family.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Based on what has been documented in the literature, a program to promote sleep health has been developed for a group of workers at high risk of developing sleep symptoms and their consequences. The workplace sleep health promotion program, including training courses and self-managed improvements of sleep hygiene, such as naps and other sleepiness countermeasures, is currently being implemented in a high-stress risk population, a flying column of police officers.
